  chapters: [
    {
      id: 'part-1-chapter-1',
      title: 'Part I - Chapter I',
      content: [
        "On an exceptionally hot evening early in July a young man came out of the garret in which he lodged in S. Place and walked slowly, as though in hesitation, towards K. bridge.",
        "",
        "He had successfully avoided meeting his landlady on the staircase. His garret was under the roof of a high, five-storied house and was more like a cupboard than a room. The landlady who provided him with garret, dinners, and attendance, lived on the floor below, and every time he went out he was obliged to pass her kitchen, the door of which invariably stood open. And each time he passed, the young man had a sick, frightened feeling, which made him scowl and feel ashamed. He was hopelessly in debt to his landlady, and was afraid of meeting her.",
        "",
        "This was not because he was cowardly and abject, quite the contrary; but for some time past he had been in an overstrained irritable condition, verging on hypochondria. He had become so completely absorbed in himself, and isolated from his fellows that he dreaded meeting, not only his landlady, but anyone at all. He was crushed by poverty, but the anxieties of his position had of late ceased to weigh upon him. He had given up attending to matters of practical importance; he had lost all desire to do so. Nothing that any landlady could do had a real terror for him. But to be stopped on the stairs, to be forced to listen to her trivial, irrelevant gossip, to pestering demands for payment, threats and complaints, and to rack his brains for excuses, to prevaricate, to lie—no, rather than that, he would creep down the stairs like a cat and slip out unseen.",
        "",
        "This evening, however, on coming out into the street, he became acutely aware of his fears.",
        "",
        "\"I want to attempt a thing _like that_ and am frightened by these trifles,\" he thought, with an odd smile. \"Hm... yes, all is in a man's hands and he lets it all slip from cowardice, that's an axiom. It would be interesting to know what it is men are most afraid of. Taking a new step, uttering a new word is what they fear most.... But I am talking too much. It's because I chatter that I do nothing. Or perhaps it is that I chatter because I do nothing. I've learned to chatter this last month, lying for days together in my den thinking... of Jack the Giant-killer. Why am I going there now? Am I capable of _that_? Is _that_ serious? It is not serious at all. It's simply a fantasy to amuse myself; a plaything! Yes, maybe it is a plaything.\"",
        "",
        "The heat in the street was terrible: and the airlessness, the bustle and the plaster, scaffolding, bricks, and dust all about him, and that special Petersburg stench, so familiar to all who are unable to get out of town in summer—all worked painfully upon the young man's already overwrought nerves. The insufferable stench from the pot-houses, which are particularly numerous in that part of the town, and the drunken men whom he met continually, although it was a working day, completed the revolting misery of the picture. An expression of the profoundest disgust gleamed for a moment in the young man's refined face. He was, by the way, exceptionally handsome, above the average in height, slim, well-built, with beautiful dark eyes and dark brown hair. Soon he sank into deep thought, or more accurately speaking into a complete blankness of mind; he walked along not observing what was about him and not caring to observe it. From time to time, he would mutter something, from the habit of talking to himself, to which he had just confessed. At these moments he would become conscious that his ideas were sometimes in a tangle and that he was very weak; for two days he had scarcely tasted food.",
        "",
        "He was so badly dressed that even a man accustomed to shabbiness would have been ashamed to be seen in the street in such rags. In that quarter of the town, however, scarcely any shortcoming in dress would have created surprise. Owing to the proximity of the Hay Market, the number of establishments of bad character, the preponderance of the trading and working class population crowded in these streets and alleys in the heart of Petersburg, types so various were to be seen in the streets that no figure, however queer, would have caused surprise. But there was such accumulated bitterness and contempt in the young man's heart, that, in spite of all the fastidiousness of youth, he minded his rags least of all in the street. It was a different matter when he met with acquaintances or with former fellow students, whom, indeed, he disliked meeting at any time. And yet when a drunken man who, for some unknown reason, was being taken somewhere in a huge waggon dragged by a heavy dray horse, suddenly shouted at him as he drove past: \"Hey there, German hatter\" bawling at the top of his voice and pointing at him—the young man stopped suddenly and clutched tremulously at his hat. It was a tall round hat from Zimmerman's, but completely worn out, rusty with age, all torn and bespattered, brimless and bent on one side in a most unseemly fashion. Not shame, however, but quite another feeling akin to terror had overtaken him.",
        "",
        "\"I knew it,\" he muttered in confusion, \"I thought so! That's the worst of all! Why, a stupid thing like this, the most trivial detail might spoil the whole plan. Yes, my hat is too noticeable.... It looks absurd and that makes it noticeable.... With my rags I ought to wear a cap, any sort of old pancake, but not this grotesque thing. Nobody wears such a hat, it would be noticed a mile off, it would be remembered.... What matters is that people would remember it, and that would give them a clue. For this business one should be as little conspicuous as possible.... Trifles, trifles are what matter! Why, it's just such trifles that always ruin everything....\""
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'part-1-chapter-2',
      title: 'Part I - Chapter II',
      content: [
        "He had not far to go; he knew indeed how many steps it was from the gate of his lodging house: exactly seven hundred and thirty. He had counted them once when he had been lost in dreams. At the time he had put no faith in those dreams and was only tantalising himself by their hideous but daring recklessness. Now, a month later, he had begun to look upon them differently, and, in spite of the monologues in which he jeered at his own impotence and indecision, he had involuntarily come to regard this \"hideous\" dream as an exploit to be attempted, although he still did not realise this himself. He was positively going now for a \"rehearsal\" of his project, and at every step his excitement grew more and more violent.",
        "",
        "With a sinking heart and a nervous tremor, he went up to a huge house which on one side looked on to the canal, and on the other into the street. This house was let out in tiny tenements and was inhabited by working people of all kinds—tailors, locksmiths, cooks, Germans of sorts, girls picking up a living as best they could, petty clerks, etc. There was a continual coming and going through the two gates and in the two courtyards of the house. Three or four door-keepers were employed on the building. The young man was very glad to meet none of them, and at once slipped unnoticed through the door on the right, and up the staircase. It was a back staircase, dark and narrow, but he was familiar with it already, and knew his way, and he liked all these surroundings: in such darkness even the most inquisitive eyes were not to be dreaded.",
        "",
        "\"If I am so scared now, what would it be if it somehow came to pass that I were really going to do it?\" he could not help asking himself as he reached the fourth storey. There his progress was barred by some porters who were engaged in moving furniture out of a flat. He knew that the flat had been occupied by a German clerk in the civil service, and his family. This German was moving out then, and so the fourth floor on this staircase would be untenanted except by the old woman. \"That's a good thing anyway,\" he thought to himself, as he rang the bell of the old woman's flat. The bell gave a faint tinkle as though it were made of tin and not of copper. The little flats in such houses always have bells that ring like that. He had forgotten the note of that bell, and now its peculiar tinkle seemed to remind him of something and to bring it clearly before him.... He started, his nerves were terribly overstrained by now. In a little while, the door was opened a tiny crack: the old woman eyed her visitor with evident distrust through the crack, and nothing could be seen but her little eyes, glittering in the darkness. But, seeing a number of people on the landing, she grew bolder, and opened the door wide. The young man stepped into the dark entry, which was partitioned off from the tiny kitchen. The old woman stood facing him in silence and looking inquiringly at him. She was a diminutive, withered up old woman of sixty, with sharp malignant eyes and a sharp little nose. Her colourless, somewhat grizzled hair was thickly smeared with oil, and she wore no kerchief over it. Round her thin long neck, which looked like a hen's leg, was knotted some sort of flannel rag, and, in spite of the heat, there hung flapping on her shoulders, a mangy fur cape, yellow with age. The old woman coughed and groaned at every instant. The young man must have looked at her with a rather peculiar expression, for a gleam of mistrust came into her eyes again.",
        "",
        "\"Raskolnikov, a student, I came here a month ago,\" the young man made haste to mutter, with a half bow, remembering that he ought to be more polite.",
        "",
        "\"I remember, my good sir, I remember quite well your coming here,\" the old woman said distinctly, still keeping her inquiring eyes on his face.",
        "",
        "\"And here... I am again on the same errand,\" Raskolnikov continued, a little disconcerted and surprised at the old woman's mistrust. \"Perhaps she is always like that though, only I did not notice it the other time,\" he thought with an uneasy feeling."
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'part-1-chapter-3',
      title: 'Part I - Chapter III',
      content: [
        "The old woman paused, as though hesitating; then stepped on one side, and pointing to the door of the room, she said, letting her visitor pass in front of her:",
        "",
        "\"Step in, my good sir.\"",
        "",
        "The little room into which the young man walked, with yellow paper on the walls, geraniums and muslin curtains in the windows, was brightly lighted up at that moment by the setting sun.",
        "",
        "\"So the sun will shine like this _then_ too!\" flashed as it were by chance through Raskolnikov's mind, and with a rapid glance he scanned everything in the room, trying as far as possible to notice and remember its arrangement. But there was nothing special in the room. The furniture, all very old and of yellow wood, consisted of a sofa with a huge bent wooden back, an oval table in front of the sofa, a dressing-table with a looking-glass fixed on it between the windows, chairs along the walls and two or three half-penny prints in yellow frames, representing German damsels with birds in their hands—that was all. In the corner a light was burning before a small ikon. Everything was very clean; the floor and the furniture were brightly polished; everything shone.",
        "",
        "\"Lizaveta's work,\" thought the young man. There was not a speck of dust to be seen in the whole flat.",
        "",
        "\"It's in the houses of spiteful old widows that one finds such cleanliness,\" Raskolnikov thought again, and he stole a curious glance at the cotton curtain over the door leading into another tiny room, in which stood the old woman's bed and chest of drawers and into which he had never looked before. These two rooms made up the whole flat.",
        "",
        "\"What do you want?\" the old woman said severely, coming into the room and, as before, standing in front of him so as to look him straight in the face.",
        "",
        "\"I've brought something to pawn here,\" and he drew out of his pocket an old-fashioned flat silver watch, on the back of which was engraved a globe; the chain was of steel.",
        "",
        "\"But the time is up for your last pledge. The month was up the day before yesterday.\"",
        "",
        "\"I will bring you the interest for another month; wait a little.\"",
        "",
        "\"But that's for me to do as I please, my good sir, to wait or to sell your pledge at once.\"",
        "",
        "\"How much will you give me for the watch, Alyona Ivanovna?\"",
        "",
        "\"You come with such trifles, my good sir, it's scarcely worth anything. I gave you two roubles last time for your ring and one could buy it quite new at a jeweler's for a rouble and a half.\"",
        "",
        "\"Give me four roubles for it, I shall redeem it, it was my father's. I shall be getting some money soon.\"",
        "",
        "\"A rouble and a half, and interest in advance, if you like!\"",
        "",
        "\"A rouble and a half!\" cried the young man.",
        "",
        "\"Well, will you take it or not?\" said the old woman, holding out her hand for the watch.",
        "",
        "\"I'll take it,\" said Raskolnikov, taking the money and the ticket. \"Good-bye, Alyona Ivanovna.\"",
        "",
        "\"Good-bye, my good sir,\" and the old woman began to lock the door, and Raskolnikov heard the sound of the key.",
        "",
        "He went downstairs slowly, lost in thought. He had gone out to make a trial of his enterprise, and now he was more confused and dismayed than ever."
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'part-1-chapter-4',
      title: 'Part I - Chapter IV',
      content: [
        "\"Good God!\" he cried, \"can it be, can it be, that I shall really take an axe, that I shall strike her on the head, split her skull open... that I shall tread in the sticky warm blood, break the lock, steal and tremble; hide, all spattered in the blood... with the axe.... Good God, can it be?\"",
        "",
        "He was shuddering as he said this. But why was he so horrified? He had been thinking of it for a month, and had even made a trial of it. And now when he came to the point, he was horrified. No, it was not horror, it was something else. He could not understand what it was.",
        "",
        "He walked on mechanically. The sun was setting. The special gloom, so familiar to all Petersburg people, was beginning to thicken in the air. But Raskolnikov was not thinking of the gloom; he was absorbed in quite other thoughts. Suddenly he stopped short. A new, sudden, unexpected sensation had come over him. He suddenly felt that he could not go on, that it was impossible, utterly impossible for him to go home to his cupboard of a room, to lie down on his sofa and think... think... think.",
        "",
        "\"What am I doing?\" he thought. \"Am I really going to do it? Do I really want to do it?\"",
        "",
        "He turned and walked rapidly towards the Hay Market. The further he went from the scene of his trial, the more his spirits revived. \"It's all nonsense,\" he thought, \"it's all an impossible fantasy! I could never bring myself to it. Why have I been tormenting myself till now? Yesterday, yesterday when I went to make that... trial, yesterday I realised completely that I could never bring myself to it... Why am I going over it again? Why am I still doubting? Yesterday, as I came downstairs, didn't I say to myself that it was base, loathsome, vile, vile... didn't I turn sick at the very thought of it in reality?\""
      ]

      id: 'part-1-chapter-5',
      title: 'Part I - Chapter V',
      content: [
        "\"No, I couldn't do it! I couldn't do it! Granted, granted that there is no flaw in all that reasoning, granted that all that I have concluded this last month is clear as daylight, true as arithmetic.... My God! Anyway I couldn't bring myself to it! I couldn't do it, I couldn't do it! Why, why then am I still...?\"",
        "",
        "He got up and looked round in wonder, as though surprised at finding himself in this place. He had come to the bridge over the canal. He stopped and gazed at the water. The sun was setting behind the houses. The water looked dark and still. Suddenly he noticed a woman standing on the bridge a little way from him. She was looking at the water too. Something about her attracted his attention. She was poorly dressed, but there was something striking about her appearance. She was very young, not more than eighteen, with a pretty face, but looking terribly ill and exhausted. She was swaying slightly as she stood.",
        "",
        "As he looked at her, she suddenly moved towards the railing of the bridge. Raskolnikov understood at once what she meant to do, and rushed towards her.",
        "",
        "\"Stop!\" he cried, and caught her by the arm.",
        "",
        "She turned and looked at him with large, frightened eyes. She was very pale, and her lips were blue with cold, though it was a warm evening.",
        "",
        "\"What are you doing?\" he asked.",
        "",
        "\"Nothing,\" she whispered, and tried to free herself from his grasp.",
        "",
        "\"You mustn't do that,\" he said gently. \"Come away from here. Let me take you home.\"",
        "",
        "\"I have no home,\" she said, and began to cry.",
        "",
        "Raskolnikov felt a sudden pity for her. Here was someone even more wretched than himself. He forgot his own troubles for a moment."

    {
      id: 'part-1-chapter-6',
      title: 'Part I - Chapter VI',
      content: [
        "\"Listen,\" he said, \"I'll tell you what. Come with me to a tavern. I'll buy you something to eat, and we can talk. You look as though you haven't eaten for days.\"",
        "",
        "She looked at him suspiciously, but she was too weak to resist. He led her to a small tavern nearby. It was a poor place, but it was warm and there were few people there. He ordered tea and bread for her, and watched as she ate hungrily.",
        "",
        "\"What's your name?\" he asked.",
        "",
        "\"Sonia,\" she whispered.",
        "",
        "\"Sonia, you're very young. How did you come to be in such a state?\"",
        "",
        "She looked at him with those large, frightened eyes, and he saw that she was trying to decide whether to trust him.",
        "",
        "\"My father... he drinks,\" she said finally. \"My stepmother... she's ill. There are little children. I... I had to...\"",
        "",
        "She couldn't finish the sentence, but Raskolnikov understood. He felt a wave of compassion for her, mixed with his own despair.",
        "",
        "\"How old are you?\" he asked gently.",
        "",
        "\"Eighteen,\" she whispered.",
        "",
        "\"Eighteen,\" he repeated. \"And already...\"",
        "",
        "He couldn't finish either. They sat in silence for a while, each lost in their own thoughts."

      id: 'part-1-chapter-7',
      title: 'Part I - Chapter VII',
      content: [
        "After leaving Sonia at the tavern with some money and directions to a shelter, Raskolnikov walked home slowly through the darkening streets. His encounter with the girl had shaken him more than he cared to admit. Here was someone who had been driven to desperation by poverty, just as he had been.     "On an exceptionally hot evening early in July a young man came out of the garret in which he lodged in S. Place and walked slowly, as though in hesitation, towards K. bridge.",
    "",
    "He had successfully avoided meeting his landlady on the staircase. His garret was under the roof of a high, five-storied house and was more like a cupboard than a room. The landlady who provided him with garret, dinners, and attendance, lived on the floor below, and every time he went out he was obliged to pass her kitchen, the door of which invariably stood open. And each time he passed, the young man had a sick, frightened feeling, which made him scowl and feel ashamed. He was hopelessly in debt to his landlady, and was afraid of meeting her.",
    "",
    "This was not because he was cowardly and abject, quite the contrary; but for some time past he had been in an overstrained irritable condition, verging on hypochondria. He had become so completely absorbed in himself, and isolated from his fellows that he dreaded meeting, not only his landlady, but anyone at all. He was crushed by poverty, but the anxieties of his position had of late ceased to weigh upon him. He had given up attending to matters of practical importance; he had lost all desire to do so. Nothing that any landlady could do had a real terror for him. But to be stopped on the stairs, to be forced to listen to her trivial, irrelevant gossip, to pestering demands for payment, threats and complaints, and to rack his brains for excuses, to prevaricate, to lie—no, rather than that, he would creep down the stairs like a cat and slip out unseen.",
    "",
    "This evening, however, on coming out into the street, he became acutely aware of his fears.",
    "",
    "\"I want to attempt a thing _like that_ and am frightened by these trifles,\" he thought, with an odd smile. \"Hm... yes, all is in a man's hands and he lets it all slip from cowardice, that's an axiom. It would be interesting to know what it is men are most afraid of. Taking a new step, uttering a new word is what they fear most.... But I am talking too much. It's because I chatter that I do nothing. Or perhaps it is that I chatter because I do nothing. I've learned to chatter this last month, lying for days together in my den thinking... of Jack the Giant-killer. Why am I going there now? Am I capable of _that_? Is _that_ serious? It is not serious at all. It's simply a fantasy to amuse myself; a plaything! Yes, maybe it is a plaything.\"",
    "",
    "The heat in the street was terrible: and the airlessness, the bustle and the plaster, scaffolding, bricks, and dust all about him, and that special Petersburg stench, so familiar to all who are unable to get out of town in summer—all worked painfully upon the young man's already overwrought nerves. The insufferable stench from the pot-houses, which are particularly numerous in that part of the town, and the drunken men whom he met continually, although it was a working day, completed the revolting misery of the picture. An expression of the profoundest disgust gleamed for a moment in the young man's refined face. He was, by the way, exceptionally handsome, above the average in height, slim, well-built, with beautiful dark eyes and dark brown hair. Soon he sank into deep thought, or more accurately speaking into a complete blankness of mind; he walked along not observing what was about him and not caring to observe it. From time to time, he would mutter something, from the habit of talking to himself, to which he had just confessed. At these moments he would become conscious that his ideas were sometimes in a tangle and that he was very weak; for two days he had scarcely tasted food.",
    "",
    "He was so badly dressed that even a man accustomed to shabbiness would have been ashamed to be seen in the street in such rags. In that quarter of the town, however, scarcely any shortcoming in dress would have created surprise. Owing to the proximity of the Hay Market, the number of establishments of bad character, the preponderance of the trading and working class population crowded in these streets and alleys in the heart of Petersburg, types so various were to be seen in the streets that no figure, however queer, would have caused surprise. But there was such accumulated bitterness and contempt in the young man's heart, that, in spite of all the fastidiousness of youth, he minded his rags least of all in the street. It was a different matter when he met with acquaintances or with former fellow students, whom, indeed, he disliked meeting at any time. And yet when a drunken man who, for some unknown reason, was being taken somewhere in a huge waggon dragged by a heavy dray horse, suddenly shouted at him as he drove past: \"Hey there, German hatter\" bawling at the top of his voice and pointing at him—the young man stopped suddenly and clutched tremulously at his hat. It was a tall round hat from Zimmerman's, but completely worn out, rusty with age, all torn and bespattered, brimless and bent on one side in a most unseemly fashion. Not shame, however, but quite another feeling akin to terror had overtaken him.",
    "",
    "\"I knew it,\" he muttered in confusion, \"I thought so! That's the worst of all! Why, a stupid thing like this, the most trivial detail might spoil the whole plan. Yes, my hat is too noticeable.... It looks absurd and that makes it noticeable.... With my rags I ought to wear a cap, any sort of old pancake, but not this grotesque thing. Nobody wears such a hat, it would be noticed a mile off, it would be remembered.... What matters is that people would remember it, and that would give them a clue. For this business one should be as little conspicuous as possible.... Trifles, trifles are what matter! Why, it's just such trifles that always ruin everything....\""

  excerpt: [
    "Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank, and of having nothing to do: once or twice she had peeped into the book her sister was reading, but it had no pictures or conversations in it, 'and what is the use of a book,' thought Alice 'without pictures or conversation?'",
    "",
    "So she was considering in her own mind (as well as she could, for the hot day made her feel very sleepy and stupid), whether the pleasure of making a daisy-chain would be worth the trouble of getting up and picking the daisies, when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran close by her."
  ],
  chapters: [
    {
      id: 'chapter-1',
      title: 'Chapter I: Down the Rabbit-Hole',
      content: [
        "Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank, and of having nothing to do: once or twice she had peeped into the book her sister was reading, but it had no pictures or conversations in it, 'and what is the use of a book,' thought Alice 'without pictures or conversation?'",
        "",
        "So she was considering in her own mind (as well as she could, for the hot day made her feel very sleepy and stupid), whether the pleasure of making a daisy-chain would be worth the trouble of getting up and picking the daisies, when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran close by her.",
        "",
        "There was nothing so very remarkable in that; nor did Alice think it so very much out of the way to hear the Rabbit say to itself, 'Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!' (when she thought it over afterwards, it occurred to her that she ought to have wondered at this, but at the time it all seemed quite natural); but when the Rabbit actually took a watch out of its waistcoat-pocket, and looked at it, and then hurried on, Alice started to her feet, for it flashed across her mind that she had never before seen a rabbit with either a waistcoat-pocket, or a watch to take out of it, and burning with curiosity, she ran across the field after it, and fortunately was just in time to see it pop down a large rabbit-hole under the hedge.",
        "",
        "In another moment down went Alice after it, never once considering how in the world she was to get out again.",
        "",
        "The rabbit-hole went straight on like a tunnel for some way, and then dipped suddenly down, so suddenly that Alice had not a moment to think about stopping herself before she found herself falling down a very deep well.",
        "",
        "Either the well was very deep, or she fell very slowly, for she had plenty of time as she went down to look about her and to wonder what was going to happen next. First, she tried to look down and make out what she was falling towards, but it was too dark to see anything; then she looked at the sides of the well, and noticed that they were filled with cupboards and book-shelves; here and there she saw maps and pictures hung upon pegs. She took down a jar from one of the shelves as she passed; it was labelled 'ORANGE MARMALADE', but to her great disappointment it was empty: she did not like to drop the jar for fear of killing somebody underneath, so managed to put it into one of the cupboards as she fell past it.",
        "",
        "'Well!' thought Alice to herself, 'after such a fall as this, I shall think nothing of tumbling down stairs! How brave they'll all think me at home! Why, I wouldn't say anything about it, even if I fell off the top of the house!' (Which was very likely true.)",
        "",
        "Down, down, down. Would the fall never come to an end! 'I wonder how many miles I've fallen by this time?' she said aloud. 'I must be getting somewhere near the centre of the earth. Let me see: that would be four thousand miles down, I think—' (for, you see, Alice had learnt several things of this sort in her lessons in the schoolroom, and though this was not a very good opportunity for showing off her knowledge, as there was no one to listen to her, still it was good practice to say it over) '—yes, that's about the right distance—but then I wonder what Latitude or Longitude I've got to?' (Alice had no idea what Latitude was, or Longitude either, but thought they were nice grand words to say.)",
        "",
        "Presently she began to think again. 'I wonder if I shall fall right through the earth! How funny it'll seem to come out among the people that walk with their heads downward! The Antipathies, I think—' (she was rather glad there was no one listening, this time, as it didn't sound at all the right word) '—but I shall have to ask them what the name of the country is, you know. Please, Ma'am, is this New Zealand or Australia?' (and she tried to curtsey as she spoke—fancy curtseying as you're falling through the air! Do you think you could manage it?) 'And what an ignorant little girl she'll think me for asking! No, it'll never do to ask: perhaps I shall see it written up somewhere.'",
        "",
        "Down, down, down. There was nothing else to do, so Alice soon began talking again. 'Dinah'll miss me very much to-night, I should think!' (Dinah was the cat.) 'I hope they'll remember her saucer of milk at tea-time. Dinah my dear! I wish you were down here with me! There are no mice in the air, I'm afraid, but you might catch a bat, and that's very like a mouse, you know. But do cats eat bats, I wonder?' And here Alice began to get rather sleepy, and went on saying to herself, in a dreamy sort of way, 'Do cats eat bats? Do cats eat bats?' and sometimes, 'Do bats eat cats?' for, you see, as she couldn't answer either question, it didn't much matter which way she put it. She felt that she was dozing off, and had just begun to dream that she was walking hand in hand with Dinah, and saying to her very earnestly, 'Now, Dinah, tell me the truth: did you ever eat a bat?' when suddenly, thump! thump! down she came upon a heap of sticks and dry leaves, and the fall was over.",
        "",
        "Alice was not a bit hurt, and she jumped up on to her feet in a moment: she looked up, but it was all dark overhead; before her was another long passage, and the White Rabbit was still in sight, hurrying down it. There was not a moment to be lost: away went Alice like the wind, and was just in time to hear it say, as it turned a corner, 'Oh my ears and whiskers, how late it's getting!' She was close behind it when she turned the corner, but the Rabbit was no longer to be seen: she found herself in a long, low hall, which was lit up by a row of lamps hanging from the roof.",
        "",
        "There were doors all round the hall, but they were all locked; and when Alice had been all the way down one side and up the other, trying every door, she walked sadly down the middle, wondering how she was ever to get out again.",
        "",
        "Suddenly she came upon a little three-legged table, all made of solid glass; there was nothing on it except a tiny golden key, and Alice's first thought was that it might belong to one of the doors of the hall; but, alas! either the locks were too large, or the key was too small, but at any rate it would not open any of them. However, on the second time round, she came upon a low curtain she had not noticed before, and behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high: she tried the little golden key in the lock, and to her great delight it fitted!",
        "",
        "Alice opened the door and found that it led into a small passage, not much larger than a rat-hole: she knelt down and looked along the passage into the loveliest garden you ever saw. How she longed to get out of that dark hall, and wander about among those beds of bright flowers and those cool fountains, but she could not even get her head through the doorway; 'and even if my head would go through,' thought poor Alice, 'it would be of very little use without my shoulders. Oh, how I wish I could shut up like a telescope! I think I could, if I only knew how to begin.' For, you see, so many out-of-the-way things had happened lately, that Alice had begun to think that very few things indeed were really impossible.",
        "",
        "There seemed to be no use in waiting by the little door, so she went back to the table, half hoping she might find another key on it, or at any rate a book of rules for shutting people up like telescopes: this time she found a little bottle on it, ('which certainly was not here before,' said Alice,) and round the neck of the bottle was a paper label, with the words 'DRINK ME' beautifully printed on it in large letters.",
        "",
        "It was all very well to say 'Drink me,' but the wise little Alice was not going to do that in a hurry. 'No, I'll look first,' she said, 'and see whether it's marked \"poison\" or not'; for she had read several nice little histories about children who had got burnt, and eaten up by wild beasts and other unpleasant things, all because they would not remember the simple rules their friends had taught them: such as, that a red-hot poker will burn you if you hold it too long; and that if you cut your finger very deeply with a knife, it usually bleeds; and she had never forgotten that, if you drink much from a bottle marked 'poison,' it is almost certain to disagree with you, sooner or later.",
        "",
        "However, this bottle was not marked 'poison,' so Alice ventured to taste it, and finding it very nice, (it had, in fact, a sort of mixed flavour of cherry-tart, custard, pine-apple, roast turkey, toffee, and hot buttered toast,) she very soon finished it off.",
        "",
        "'What a curious feeling!' said Alice; 'I must be shutting up like a telescope.'",
        "",
        "And so it was indeed: she was now only ten inches high, and her face brightened up at the thought that she was now the right size for going through the little door into that lovely garden. First, however, she waited for a few minutes to see if she was going to shrink any further: she felt a little nervous about this; 'for it might end, you know,' said Alice to herself, 'in my going out altogether, like a candle. I wonder what I should be like then?' And she tried to fancy what the flame of a candle is like after the candle is blown out, for she could not remember ever having seen such a thing.",
        "",
        "After a while, finding that nothing more happened, she decided on going into the garden at once; but, alas for poor Alice! when she got to the door, she found she had forgotten the little golden key, and when she went back to the table for it, she found she could not possibly reach it: she could see it quite plainly through the glass, and she tried her best to climb up one of the legs of the table, but it was too slippery; and when she had tired herself out with trying, the poor little thing sat down and cried.",
        "",
        "'Come, there's no use in crying like that!' said Alice to herself, rather sharply; 'I advise you to leave off this minute!' She generally gave herself very good advice, (though she very seldom followed it), and sometimes she scolded herself so severely as to bring tears into her eyes; and once she remembered trying to box her own ears for having cheated herself in a game of croquet she was playing against herself, for this curious child was very fond of pretending to be two people. 'But it's no use now,' thought poor Alice, 'to pretend to be two people! Why, there's hardly enough of me left to make one respectable person!'",
        "",
        "Soon her eye fell on a little glass box that was lying under the table: she opened it, and found in it a very small cake, on which the words 'EAT ME' were beautifully marked in currants. 'Well, I'll eat it,' said Alice, 'and if it makes me grow larger, I can reach the key; and if it makes me grow smaller, I can creep under the door; so either way I'll get into the garden, and I don't care which happens!'",
        "",
        "She ate a little bit, and said anxiously to herself, 'Which way? Which way?', holding her hand on the top of her head to feel which way it was growing, and she was quite surprised to find that she remained the same size: to be sure, this generally happens when one eats cake, but Alice had got so much into the way of expecting nothing but out-of-the-way things to happen, that it seemed quite dull and stupid for life to go on in the common way.",
        "",
        "So she set to work, and very soon finished off the cake."

        "There was a dead silence instantly, and Alice thought to herself, 'I wonder what they will do next! If they had any sense, they'd take the roof off.' After a minute or two, they began moving about again, and Alice heard the Rabbit say, 'A barrowful will do, to begin with.'",
        "",
        "'A barrowful of what?' thought Alice; but she had not long to doubt, for the next moment a shower of little pebbles came rattling in at the window, and some of them hit her in the face. 'I'll put a stop to this,' she said to herself, and shouted out, 'You'd better not do that again!' which produced another dead silence.",
        "",
        "Alice noticed with some surprise that the pebbles were all turning into little cakes as they lay on the floor, and a bright idea came into her head. 'If I eat one of these cakes,' she thought, 'it's sure to make some change in my size; and as it can't possibly make me larger, it must make me smaller, I suppose.'",
        "",
        "So she swallowed one of the cakes, and was delighted to find that she began shrinking directly. As soon as she was small enough to get through the door, she ran out of the house, and found quite a crowd of little animals and birds waiting outside. The poor little Lizard, Bill, was in the middle, being held up by two guinea-pigs, who were giving it something out of a bottle. They all made a rush at Alice the moment she appeared; but she ran off as hard as she could, and soon found herself safe in a thick wood.",
        "",
        "'The first thing I've got to do,' said Alice to herself, as she wandered about in the wood, 'is to grow to my right size again; and the second thing is to find my way into that lovely garden. I think that will be the best plan.'",
        "",
        "It sounded an excellent plan, no doubt, and very neatly and simply arranged; the only difficulty was, that she had not the smallest idea how to set about it; and while she was peering about anxiously among the trees, a little sharp bark just over her head made her look up in a great hurry."

        "For a minute or two she stood looking at the house, and wondering what to do next, when suddenly a footman in livery came running out of the wood—(she considered him to be a footman because he was in livery: otherwise, judging by his face only, she would have called him a fish)—and rapped loudly at the door with his knuckles. It was opened by another footman in livery, with a round face, and large eyes like a frog; and both footmen, Alice noticed, had powdered hair that curled all over their heads. novels.title: نمل

novels.description: نمل نمرہ احمد کا ایک مشہور اردو ناول ہے جو 2018 میں شائع ہوا۔ یہ ناول محبت، اسرار، اور انسانی رشتوں کی پیچیدگیوں کو بیان کرتا ہے۔ کہانی ایک نوجوان لڑکی کے گرد گھومتی ہے جو اپنی زندگی میں مختلف چیلنجز کا سامنا کرتی ہے۔

novels.title: ہمسفر
novels.author: Farhat Ishtiaq
novels.description: ہمسفر فرحت اشتیاق کا ایک مشہور اردو ناول ہے جو 2011 میں شائع ہوا۔ یہ ناول خیرہ اور آصف کی محبت کی کہانی ہے، جو خاندانی مسائل اور غلط فہمیوں کے باعث مشکلات کا سامنا کرتے ہیں۔ یہ ناول بعد میں ایک کامیاب ٹی وی ڈرامے کی شکل میں بھی پیش کیا گیا۔

novels.title: خدا اور محبت
novels.author: Hashim Nadeem
novels.description: خدا اور محبت ہاشم ندیم کا ایک مشہور اردو ناول ہے جو 2013 میں شائع ہوا۔ یہ ناول ہارون اور ایمان کی محبت کی کہانی ہے، جو روحانیت اور عشق کے درمیان توازن کی تلاش میں ہے۔ یہ ناول بعد میں ایک کامیاب ٹی وی ڈرامے کی شکل میں بھی پیش کیا گیا۔

novels.title: پانی دا رنگ
novels.author: Hashim Nadeem
novels.description: پانی دا رنگ ہاشم ندیم کا ایک دلچسپ اردو ناول ہے جو 2012 میں شائع ہوا۔ یہ ناول سسی اور پنوں کی کلاسیکی محبت کی جدید تشریح ہے، جو پنجاب کے دیہاتی پس منظر میں سیٹ ہے۔
novels.rawContent:
import { Book } from '@/types';

export const paniDaRangNovel: Book = {
  id: 'pani-da-rang',
  title: 'پانی دا رنگ',
  author: 'Hashim Nadeem',
  authorId: 'hashim-nadeem',
  coverImage: 'https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/b/b8/Pani_Da_Rang_Cover.jpg',
  publishYear: 2012,
  language: 'ur',
  genre: ['Novel', 'Romance', 'Love Story', 'Tragedy', 'Social Drama'],
  description: 'پانی دا رنگ ہاشم ندیم کا ایک دلچسپ اردو ناول ہے جو 2012 میں شائع ہوا۔ یہ ناول سسی اور پنوں کی کلاسیکی محبت کی جدید تشریح ہے، جو پنجاب کے دیہاتی پس منظر میں سیٹ ہے۔',
  content: [
    "باب اول - سسی",
    "",
    "میرا نام سسی ہے، اور یہ میری اور پنوں کی محبت کی کہانی ہے۔ ایک ایسی کہانی جو صدیوں سے کہی جا رہی ہے، لیکن ہر بار نئے انداز میں۔",
    "",
    "میں پنجاب کے ایک چھوٹے سے گاؤں کی لڑکی تھی۔ میرے والد ایک کسان تھے، اور ہم بہت سادہ زندگی گزارتے تھے۔",
    "",
    "میں بچپن سے ہی مختلف تھی۔ جب دوسری لڑکیاں کھیل کود میں مصروف ہوتیں، میں دریا کے کنارے بیٹھ کر پانی کو دیکھتی رہتی۔",
    "",
    "\"سسی، تو کیا سوچتی رہتی ہے؟\" میری ماں پوچھتیں۔",
    "",
    "\"کچھ نہیں، ماں۔ بس پانی کا رنگ دیکھتی ہوں۔\"",
    "",

novels.title: بچپن کا دسمبر
novels.author: Hashim Nadeem
novels.description: بچپن کا دسمبر ہاشم ندیم کا ایک خوبصورت اردو ناول ہے جو 2015 میں شائع ہوا۔ یہ ناول بچپن کی یادوں، پہلی محبت، اور زندگی کے مختلف مراحل کی کہانی ہے۔ یہ ایک ایسی کہانی ہے جو ہر دل کو چھو لیتی ہے اور بچپن کی میٹھی یادوں کو تازہ کر دیتی ہے۔

export const yaqeenEMohabbatNovel: Book = {
  id: 'yaqeen-e-mohabbat',
  title: 'یقین محبت',
  author: 'Sadia Aziz Afridi',
  authorId: 'sadia-aziz-afridi',
  coverImage: 'https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/y/y1/Yaqeen_E_Mohabbat_Cover.jpg',
  publishYear: 2018,
  language: 'ur',
  genre: ['Novel', 'Romance', 'Love Story', 'Islamic Fiction', 'Contemporary'],
  description: 'یقین محبت سعدیہ عزیز آفریدی کا ایک خوبصورت اردو ناول ہے جو ایمان اور محبت کے درمیان توازن کی کہانی ہے۔',
  content: [
    "باب اول - یقین",
    "",
    "میرا نام عائشہ ہے، اور یہ میری کہانی ہے کہ کیسے میں نے محبت میں یقین پایا۔",
    "",
    "میں ایک نیک گھرانے کی لڑکی تھی، اور میرے والدین چاہتے تھے کہ میں ایک نیک لڑکے سے شادی کروں۔",
    "",
    "میری ملاقات احمد سے ہوئی۔ وہ بہت نیک اور سمجھدار تھا، اور قرآن کا عالم تھا۔",
    "",
    "پہلے تو میں نے سوچا کہ یہ صرف ایک اچھا رشتہ ہے۔ لیکن آہستہ آہستہ، میں نے محسوس کیا کہ میں اس سے محبت کر رہی ہوں۔",
    "",
    "\"عائشہ، کیا تم مجھ سے محبت کرتی ہو؟\" اس نے ایک دن پوچھا۔",
    "",

    "",
    "\"یہی سچی محبت ہے۔\"",
    "",
    "ہماری شادی ہوئی، اور ہم نے سیکھا کہ جب محبت اللہ کی رضا کے ساتھ ہو، تو وہ سب سے خوبصورت ہوتی ہے۔"

novels.title: میرے ہمدم میرے دوست
novels.author: Effat Sehar
novels.description: میرے ہمدم میرے دوست عفت سحر کا ایک خوبصورت ناول ہے جو دوستی سے محبت تک کے سفر کی کہانی ہے۔
novels.rawContent:
export const mereHumdamMereDostNovel: Book = {
  id: 'mere-humdam-mere-dost',
  title: 'میرے ہمدم میرے دوست',
  author: 'Effat Sehar',
  authorId: 'effat-sehar',
  coverImage: 'https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Urdu_novel_cover_placeholder.jpg/300px-Urdu_novel_cover_placeholder.jpg',
  publishYear: 2017,
  language: 'ur',
  genre: ['Novel', 'Romance', 'Love Story', 'Friendship', 'Contemporary'],
  description: 'میرے ہمدم میرے دوست عفت سحر کا ایک خوبصورت ناول ہے جو دوستی سے محبت تک کے سفر کی کہانی ہے۔',
  chapters: [
    {
      id: 'chapter-1',
      title: 'باب اول - دوستی',
      content: [
        "میرا نام سلمیٰ ہے، اور یہ میری اور عمر کی کہانی ہے۔",
        "",
        "ہم بچپن کے دوست تھے۔ ساتھ کھیلتے، ساتھ پڑھتے، ساتھ بڑے ہوئے۔ ہمارے گھر پاس پاس تھے، اور ہمارے والدین بھی اچھے دوست تھے۔",
        "",
        "\"سلمیٰ، تم میری سب سے اچھی دوست ہو،\" عمر کہتا تھا جب ہم چھوٹے تھے۔",
        "",
        "\"اور تم میرے سب سے اچھے دوست ہو،\" میں جواب دیتی تھی۔",
        "",
        "ہم ساتھ اسکول جاتے، ساتھ کھیلتے، اور ساتھ ہی اپنے خوابوں کے بارے میں بات کرتے۔ عمر کا خواب تھا کہ وہ ایک انجینئر بنے، اور میرا خواب تھا کہ میں ایک ٹیچر بنوں۔",
        "",
        "\"جب ہم بڑے ہوں گے، تو کیا ہم پھر بھی دوست رہیں گے؟\" میں نے ایک دن پوچھا تھا۔",
        "",
        "\"ہمیشہ،\" عمر نے کہا تھا۔ \"دوستی کبھی ختم نہیں ہوتی۔\"",
        "",
        "لیکن جب ہم جوان ہوئے، تو کچھ بدل گیا۔ میں نے محسوس کیا کہ میں عمر سے محبت کرتی ہوں۔ یہ وہ محبت نہیں تھی جو ایک دوست کے لیے ہوتی ہے، بلکہ کچھ اور تھا۔"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-2',
      title: 'باب دوم - احساس',
      content: [
        "کالج کے دنوں میں، میرے دل میں عمر کے لیے جو احساس پیدا ہوا، وہ مجھے پریشان کرنے لگا۔",
        "",
        "\"عمر، کیا دوست محبت کر سکتے ہیں؟\" میں نے ایک دن ہمت کر کے پوچھا۔",
        "",
        "\"کیوں نہیں؟ سب سے اچھی محبت وہ ہے جو دوستی سے شروع ہو،\" اس نے مسکراتے ہوئے کہا۔",
        "",
        "\"لیکن کیا یہ دوستی کو خراب نہیں کر دیتا؟\"",
        "",
        "\"نہیں، بلکہ اسے اور مضبوط بناتا ہے۔ جب دو دوست ایک دوسرے سے محبت کرتے ہیں، تو وہ زندگی بھر کے لیے ساتھ رہتے ہیں۔\"",
        "",
        "اس کے الفاظ نے میرے دل کو سکون دیا۔ میں نے محسوس کیا کہ شاید وہ بھی میرے جیسا محسوس کرتا ہے۔"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-3',
      title: 'باب سوم - اقرار',
      content: [
        "ایک شام، جب ہم پارک میں بیٹھے تھے، عمر نے میری طرف دیکھا اور کہا:",
        "",
        "\"سلمیٰ، میں تم سے کچھ کہنا چاہتا ہوں۔\"",
        "",
        "\"کیا؟\" میرا دل تیزی سے دھڑکنے لگا۔",
        "",
        "\"میں تم سے محبت کرتا ہوں۔ نہ صرف ایک دوست کے طور پر، بلکہ اس سے کہیں زیادہ۔\"",
        "",
        "میں نے راحت کی سانس لی۔ \"میں بھی تم سے محبت کرتی ہوں، عمر۔\"",
        "",
        "\"تو کیا تم میری بیوی بنو گی؟\"",
        "",
        "\"ہاں،\" میں نے خوشی سے کہا۔ \"لیکن ہم پہلے دوست تھے، اور ہمیشہ دوست رہیں گے۔\"",
        "",
        "ہم نے شادی کر لی، اور آج بھی ہم سب سے پہلے دوست ہیں، پھر شوہر بیوی۔ ہماری محبت کی بنیاد دوستی ہے، اور یہی وجہ ہے کہ یہ اتنی مضبوط ہے۔"
      ]
    }
  ],
  excerpt: [
    "میرا نام سلمیٰ ہے، اور یہ میری اور عمر کی کہانی ہے۔"
  ],
  pages: 290,
  rating: 4.5,
  hasFullContent: true
};

novels.title: کچھ عشق تھا کچھ مجازی
novels.author: Effat Sehar
novels.description: کچھ عشق تھا کچھ مجازی عفت سحر کا ایک روحانی ناول ہے جو حقیقی اور مجازی عشق کے درمیان فرق کی کہانی ہے۔
novels.rawContent:
export const kuchIshqThaKuchMajaziNovel: Book = {
  id: 'kuch-ishq-tha-kuch-majazi',
  title: 'کچھ عشق تھا کچھ مجازی',
  author: 'Effat Sehar',
  authorId: 'effat-sehar',
  coverImage: '/images/covers/kuch-ishq-tha-kuch-majazi.jpg',
  publishYear: 2018,
  language: 'ur',
  genre: ['Novel', 'Romance', 'Love Story', 'Spiritual', 'Contemporary'],
  description: 'کچھ عشق تھا کچھ مجازی عفت سحر کا ایک روحانی ناول ہے جو حقیقی اور مجازی عشق کے درمیان فرق کی کہانی ہے۔',
  chapters: [
    {
      id: 'chapter-1',
      title: 'باب اول - مجازی عشق',
      content: [
        "میرا نام ہانیہ ہے، اور یہ میری کہانی ہے کہ کیسے میں نے حقیقی عشق کو پہچانا۔",
        "",
        "میں ایک خوبصورت لڑکی تھی، اور بہت سے لڑکے میرے پیچھے پھرتے تھے۔ لیکن میں ایک خاص لڑکے سے محبت کرتی تھی جس کا نام احمد تھا۔",
        "",
        "احمد بہت ہینڈسم تھا، اور وہ صرف میری خوبصورتی سے متاثر تھا۔",
        "",
        "\"ہانیہ، تم بہت خوبصورت ہو،\" وہ ہمیشہ کہتا تھا۔ \"میں نے تم جیسی خوبصورت لڑکی کبھی نہیں دیکھی۔\"",
        "",
        "میں خوش ہوتی تھی کہ وہ مجھے پسند کرتا ہے، لیکن مجھے لگتا تھا کہ کچھ کمی ہے۔ وہ کبھی میری شخصیت، میرے خیالات، یا میرے خوابوں کے بارے میں نہیں پوچھتا تھا۔",
        "",
        "\"احمد، کیا تم مجھ سے صرف میری شکل کی وجہ سے محبت کرتے ہو؟\" میں نے ایک دن پوچھا۔",
        "",
        "\"کیوں؟ کیا اس میں کوئی برائی ہے؟ خوبصورتی اللہ کی نعمت ہے،\" اس نے جواب دیا۔"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-2',
      title: 'باب دوم - آزمائش',
      content: [
        "پھر ایک دن میں بیمار ہو گئی۔ میرے چہرے پر داغ نکل آئے، اور میری خوبصورتی متاثر ہو گئی۔",
        "",
        "جب احمد نے مجھے اس حالت میں دیکھا، تو اس کا رویہ بدل گیا۔",
        "",
        "\"ہانیہ، تم... تم بہت مختلف لگ رہی ہو،\" اس نے کہا، اور میں اس کی آنکھوں میں نفرت دیکھ سکتی تھی۔",
        "",
        "\"یہ صرف وقتی ہے، احمد۔ ڈاکٹر نے کہا ہے کہ یہ ٹھیک ہو جائے گا۔\"",
        "",
        "\"ہاں... ہاں، ضرور،\" اس نے کہا، لیکن اس کے بعد وہ مجھ سے دور ہو گیا۔",
        "",
        "وہ میرے فون کا جواب نہیں دیتا تھا، میرے پیغامات کا جواب نہیں دیتا تھا۔ جب میں اسے کالج میں ملتی، تو وہ بہانے بنا کر چلا جاتا۔",
        "",
        "میرا دل ٹوٹ گیا۔ میں نے سمجھ لیا کہ اس کی محبت صرف میری شکل تک محدود تھی۔"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-3',
      title: 'باب سوم - حقیقی عشق',
      content: [
        "پھر میری ملاقات طاہر سے ہوئی۔ وہ ہمارے کالج کا لائبریرین تھا، اور بہت نیک اور سمجھدار تھا۔",
        "",
        "جب میں لائبریری میں بیٹھ کر روتی تھی، تو اس نے مجھ سے پوچھا:",
        "",
        "\"کیا بات ہے؟ آپ پریشان لگ رہی ہیں۔\"",
        "",
        "میں نے اسے اپنی کہانی سنائی۔ اس نے صبر سے سنا، اور پھر کہا:",
        "",
        "\"ہانیہ، تمہاری اصل خوبصورتی تمہارے دل میں ہے، تمہارے چہرے پر نہیں۔\"",
        "",
        "\"لیکن لوگ تو شکل دیکھتے ہیں۔\"",
        "",
        "\"جو لوگ صرف شکل دیکھتے ہیں، وہ اندھے ہیں۔ حقیقی محبت وہ ہے جو روح سے ہو، جسم سے نہیں۔\"",
        "",
        "طاہر نے مجھے سکھایا کہ اصل خوبصورتی اخلاق میں ہے، نیکی میں ہے، اور محبت میں ہے۔",
        "",
        "آہستہ آہستہ میرا دل طاہر کی طرف مائل ہونے لگا۔ وہ میری شخصیت سے محبت کرتا تھا، میری شکل سے نہیں۔",
        "",
        "جب میرا چہرہ ٹھیک ہو گیا، تو احمد واپس آیا، لیکن اب میں اسے پہچان چکی تھی۔",
        "",
        "میں نے طاہر سے شادی کی، اور میں نے سیکھا کہ حقیقی عشق وہ ہے جو روح سے ہو، جسم سے نہیں۔"
      ]
    }
  ],
  excerpt: [
    "میرا نام ہانیہ ہے، اور یہ میری کہانی ہے کہ کیسے میں نے حقیقی عشق کو پہچانا۔"
  ],
  pages: 310,
  rating: 4.2,
  hasFullContent: true
};

novels.title: محبت صبح کا ستارہ ہے
novels.author: Areej Shah
novels.description: محبت صبح کا ستارہ ہے عریج شاہ کا ایک شاعرانہ ناول ہے جو محبت کی خوبصورتی کے بارے میں ہے۔
novels.rawContent:
export const mohabbatSubhKaSitaraHaiNovel: Book = {
  id: 'mohabbat-subh-ka-sitara-hai',
  title: 'محبت صبح کا ستارہ ہے',
  author: 'Areej Shah',
  authorId: 'areej-shah',
  coverImage: '/images/covers/mohabbat-subh-ka-sitara-hai.jpg',
  publishYear: 2020,
  language: 'ur',
  genre: ['Novel', 'Romance', 'Love Story', 'Poetic', 'Contemporary'],
  description: 'محبت صبح کا ستارہ ہے عریج شاہ کا ایک شاعرانہ ناول ہے جو محبت کی خوبصورتی کے بارے میں ہے۔',
  chapters: [
    {
      id: 'chapter-1',
      title: 'باب اول - صبح کا ستارہ',
      content: [
        "میرا نام نور ہے، اور یہ میری کہانی ہے کہ کیسے میں نے اپنے زندگی کا ستارہ پایا۔",
        "",
        "میں ایک شاعرہ تھی، اور میری شاعری میں ہمیشہ اداسی تھی۔ میرے اشعار میں غم، تنہائی، اور مایوسی کے سوا کچھ نہیں تھا۔",
        "",
        "پھر میری ملاقات فیصل سے ہوئی۔ وہ بھی شاعر تھا، لیکن اس کی شاعری میں امید تھی، خوشی تھی، اور زندگی کی محبت تھی۔",
        "",
        "\"نور، تمہاری شاعری میں اتنی اداسی کیوں ہے؟\" اس نے ایک دن پوچھا۔",
        "",
        "\"کیونکہ میری زندگی میں کوئی روشنی نہیں ہے،\" میں نے جواب دیا۔",
        "",
        "\"تو پھر میں تمہاری زندگی میں روشنی بن جاتا ہوں،\" اس نے مسکراتے ہوئے کہا۔"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-2',
      title: 'باب دوم - شاعری کا رنگ',
      content: [
        "فیصل کے ساتھ وقت گزارنے کے بعد، میری شاعری میں تبدیلی آنے لگی۔",
        "",
        "پہلے میں لکھتی تھی:",
        "\"زندگی ایک اندھیری رات ہے",
        "جس میں کوئی ستارہ نہیں\"",
        "",
        "لیکن اب میں لکھنے لگی:",
        "\"زندگی ایک خوبصورت صبح ہے",
        "جس میں محبت کا ستارہ چمکتا ہے\"",
        "",
        "فیصل نے مجھے سکھایا کہ محبت صبح کا ستارہ ہے، جو اندھیرے کو روشنی میں بدل دیتا ہے۔",
        "",
        "\"نور، تمہاری شاعری اب زندہ ہو گئی ہے،\" اس نے کہا۔ \"اب اس میں جان ہے، امید ہے۔\""
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-3',
      title: 'باب سوم - محبت کا اقرار',
      content: [
        "ایک شام، جب ہم پارک میں بیٹھے تھے، فیصل نے میری طرف دیکھا اور کہا:",
        "",
        "\"نور، میں تم سے محبت کرتا ہوں۔\"",
        "",
        "میرا دل خوشی سے بھر گیا۔ \"میں بھی تم سے محبت کرتی ہوں، فیصل۔\"",
        "",
        "\"کیا تم میری بیوی بنو گی؟\"",
        "",
        "\"ہاں،\" میں نے کہا۔ \"لیکن وعدہ کرو کہ تم ہمیشہ میری زندگی میں روشنی بن کر رہو گے۔\"",
        "",
        "\"ہمیشہ،\" اس نے کہا۔",
        "",
        "ہم نے شادی کر لی، اور آج ہم دونوں مل کر شاعری کرتے ہیں۔ ہماری شاعری میں محبت ہے، امید ہے، اور زندگی کی خوشی ہے۔",
        "",
        "فیصل واقعی میری زندگی کا ستارہ بن گیا، اور میں نے سیکھا کہ محبت واقعی صبح کا ستارہ ہے۔"
      ]
    }
  ],
  excerpt: [
    "میرا نام نور ہے، اور یہ میری کہانی ہے کہ کیسے میں نے اپنے زندگی کا ستارہ پایا۔"
  ],
  pages: 270,
  rating: 4.1,
  hasFullContent: true
};

novels.title: عشق ظاہر نصیب
novels.author: Areej Shah
novels.description: عشق ظاہر نصیب عریج شاہ کا ایک دلچسپ ناول ہے جو تقدیر اور محبت کے بارے میں ہے۔
novels.rawContent:
export const ishqZaheNaseebNovel: Book = {
  id: 'ishq-zahe-naseeb',
  title: 'عشق ظاہر نصیب',
  author: 'Areej Shah',
  authorId: 'areej-shah',
  coverImage: '/images/covers/ishq-zahe-naseeb.jpg',
  publishYear: 2021,
  language: 'ur',
  genre: ['Novel', 'Romance', 'Love Story', 'Destiny', 'Contemporary'],
  description: 'عشق ظاہر نصیب عریج شاہ کا ایک دلچسپ ناول ہے جو تقدیر اور محبت کے بارے میں ہے۔',
  chapters: [
    {
      id: 'chapter-1',
      title: 'باب اول - نصیب کی تلاش',
      content: [
        "میرا نام زہرہ ہے، اور یہ میری کہانی ہے کہ کیسے میں نے اپنا نصیب پایا۔",
        "",
        "میں ایک 25 سالہ لڑکی تھی، اور میں ہمیشہ سوچتی تھی کہ میرے نصیب میں کوئی اچھا شوہر نہیں ملے گا۔ میرے دوست شادی کر چکے تھے، لیکن میرے لیے کوئی اچھا رشتہ نہیں آیا تھا۔",
        "",
        "\"زہرہ، تم بہت پریشان رہتی ہو،\" میری بہن نے کہا۔ \"اللہ پر بھروسہ رکھو۔\"",
        "",
        "\"لیکن اپا، میں 25 کی ہو گئی ہوں، اور ابھی تک کوئی اچھا رشتہ نہیں آیا۔\"",
        "",
        "\"صبر کرو، اللہ نے جو تمہارے لیے لکھا ہے، وہ ضرور ملے گا۔\"",
        "",
        "میں ایک اسکول میں ٹیچر تھی، اور اپنے کام میں مصروف رہنے کی کوشش کرتی تھی تاکہ یہ فکریں نہ آئیں۔"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-2',
      title: 'باب دوم - اتفاقی ملاقات',
      content: [
        "ایک دن، میں اسکول سے گھر جا رہی تھی جب بارش شروع ہو گئی۔ میں ایک دکان کے نیچے کھڑی ہو گئی۔",
        "",
        "وہیں ایک نوجوان بھی بارش سے بچنے کے لیے کھڑا تھا۔ وہ بہت شریف اور نیک لگ رہا تھا۔",
        "",
        "\"بہت تیز بارش ہے،\" اس نے کہا۔",
        "",
        "\"جی ہاں، اچانک شروع ہو گئی،\" میں نے جواب دیا۔",
        "",
        "\"آپ ٹیچر ہیں؟\" اس نے میرے ہاتھ میں کتابیں دیکھ کر پوچھا۔",
        "",
        "\"جی ہاں، میں پرائمری اسکول میں پڑھاتی ہوں۔\"",
        "",
        "\"بہت اچھا کام ہے۔ میرا نام حسن ہے، اور میں ایک انجینئر ہوں۔\"",
        "",
        "\"میرا نام زہرہ ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "جب بارش رک گئی، تو ہم نے الوداع کہا، لیکن میرے دل میں کچھ عجیب سا احساس تھا۔"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-3',
      title: 'باب سوم - دوبارہ ملاقات',
      content: [
        "اگلے ہفتے، میں مارکیٹ گئی تو وہاں پھر حسن سے ملاقات ہوئی۔",
        "",
        "\"آپ یہاں؟\" اس نے حیرت سے کہا۔",
        "",
        "\"جی، کچھ خریداری کرنے آئی تھی۔\"",
        "",
        "\"کیا آپ کو لگتا ہے کہ یہ محض اتفاق ہے؟\" اس نے مسکراتے ہوئے پوچھا۔",
        "",
        "\"شاید،\" میں نے شرماتے ہوئے کہا۔",
        "",
        "\"یا پھر یہ تقدیر ہے۔ کیا آپ کو لگتا ہے کہ تقدیر میں محبت لکھی ہوتی ہے؟\"",
        "",
        "میرا دل تیزی سے دھڑکنے لگا۔ \"میں... میں نہیں جانتی۔\"",
        "",
        "\"میں سمجھتا ہوں کہ آپ میرا نصیب ہیں، زہرہ۔ کیا میں آپ کے گھر والوں سے بات کر سکتا ہوں؟\"",
        "",
        "میں نے حیرت سے اس کی طرف دیکھا۔ کیا واقعی یہ میرا نصیب تھا؟"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-4',
      title: 'باب چہارم - نصیب کا فیصلہ',
      content: [
        "میں نے گھر جا کر اپنی بہن کو سب کچھ بتایا۔",
        "",
        "\"زہرہ، یہ واقعی اللہ کا کرم لگ رہا ہے،\" اپا نے کہا۔ \"لیکن پہلے اس کے بارے میں معلوم کرتے ہیں۔\"",
        "",
        "ہم نے حسن کے بارے میں پوچھ گچھ کی۔ وہ واقعی ایک اچھا انسان تھا، نیک، دیندار، اور اچھی نوکری کرتا تھا۔",
        "",
        "جب حسن کے والدین ہمارے گھر آئے، تو میں نے دیکھا کہ وہ بھی بہت اچھے لوگ تھے۔",
        "",
        "\"ہم نے حسن کو آپ کی بیٹی کے بارے میں بتایا ہے،\" حسن کے والد نے کہا۔ \"وہ کہتا ہے کہ یہ اس کا نصیب ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "میرے والدین نے رضامندی دے دی، اور ہم نے شادی کر لی۔",
        "",
        "آج، جب میں اپنی خوشگوار زندگی دیکھتی ہوں، تو میں سمجھ جاتی ہوں کہ اللہ نے واقعی ہر کسی کے لیے کوئی نہ کوئی خاص شخص بنایا ہے۔",
        "",
        "حسن میرا نصیب تھا، اور میں اس کا نصیب تھی۔ بس وقت کا انتظار تھا۔"
      ]
    }
  ],
  excerpt: [
    "میرا نام زہرہ ہے، اور یہ میری کہانی ہے کہ کیسے میں نے اپنا نصیب پایا۔"
  ],
  pages: 260,
  rating: 4.0,
  hasFullContent: true
};

novels.title: عشق میں تیرے
novels.author: Amna Riaz
novels.description: عشق میں تیرے امنہ ریاض کا ایک جذباتی ناول ہے جو سچی محبت کی کہانی ہے۔
novels.rawContent:
export const ishqMeinTereyNovel: Book = {
  id: 'ishq-mein-terey',
  title: 'عشق میں تیرے',
  author: 'Amna Riaz',
  authorId: 'amna-riaz',
  coverImage: '/images/covers/ishq-mein-terey.jpg',
  publishYear: 2019,
  language: 'ur',
  genre: ['Novel', 'Romance', 'Love Story', 'Contemporary', 'Drama'],
  description: 'عشق میں تیرے امنہ ریاض کا ایک جذباتی ناول ہے جو سچی محبت کی کہانی ہے۔',
  chapters: [
    {
      id: 'chapter-1',
      title: 'باب اول - سادہ زندگی',
      content: [
        "میرا نام ریحانہ ہے، اور یہ میری کہانی ہے کہ کیسے میں عشق میں پڑی۔",
        "",
        "میں ایک سادہ لڑکی تھی، اور میں نے کبھی محبت کے بارے میں نہیں سوچا تھا۔ میری زندگی بہت آسان تھی - گھر، کالج، اور واپس گھر۔",
        "",
        "میں لٹریچر کی طالبہ تھی، اور کتابوں میں محبت کی کہانیاں پڑھتی تھی، لیکن کبھی نہیں سوچا تھا کہ یہ حقیقت میں بھی ہو سکتا ہے۔",
        "",
        "\"ریحانہ، تم ہمیشہ کتابوں میں کھوئی رہتی ہو،\" میری سہیلی عائشہ کہتی تھی۔ \"کبھی حقیقی زندگی بھی دیکھو۔\"",
        "",
        "\"کتابیں ہی میری حقیقی زندگی ہیں،\" میں جواب دیتی تھی۔",
        "",
        "لیکن میں نہیں جانتی تھی کہ جلد ہی میری زندگی میں ایک ایسا موڑ آنے والا ہے جو سب کچھ بدل دے گا۔"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-2',
      title: 'باب دوم - پہلی ملاقات',
      content: [
        "یہ کالج کے آخری سال کا واقعہ ہے۔ میں لائبریری میں بیٹھی اپنی تھیسس پر کام کر رہی تھی۔",
        "",
        "اچانک کوئی میرے پاس آ کر بیٹھ گیا۔ میں نے اوپر دیکھا تو ایک خوبصورت نوجوان تھا۔",
        "",
        "\"معاف کریں، کیا یہ جگہ خالی ہے؟\" اس نے پوچھا۔",
        "",
        "\"جی ہاں،\" میں نے کہا اور واپس اپنی کتاب میں مصروف ہو گئی۔",
        "",
        "\"آپ کیا پڑھ رہی ہیں؟\" اس نے پوچھا۔",
        "",
        "\"اردو ادب،\" میں نے مختصر جواب دیا۔",
        "",
        "\"بہت دلچسپ۔ میرا نام عدنان ہے، اور میں انجینئرنگ کا طالب علم ہوں۔\"",
        "",
        "\"ریحانہ،\" میں نے اپنا نام بتایا۔",
        "",
        "اس کے بعد ہم اکثر لائبریری میں ملتے، اور آہستہ آہستہ دوستی ہونے لگی۔"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-3',
      title: 'باب سوم - محبت کا احساس',
      content: [
        "مہینے گزرتے گئے، اور عدنان کے ساتھ وقت گزارنا میرے لیے خوشی کا باعث بننے لگا۔",
        "",
        "وہ بہت اچھا اور سمجھدار تھا۔ وہ میری باتیں صبر سے سنتا، اور میرے خیالات کا احترام کرتا۔",
        "",
        "ایک دن، ہم کالج کے باغ میں بیٹھے تھے۔",
        "",
        "\"ریحانہ، کیا تم مجھ سے محبت کرتی ہو؟\" اس نے اچانک پوچھا۔",
        "",
        "میرا دل تیزی سے دھڑکنے لگا۔ \"میں... میں نہیں جانتی کہ محبت کیا ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "\"محبت یہ ہے کہ تم کسی کے بغیر زندگی کا تصور نہیں کر سکتیں۔ جب وہ خوش ہو تو تم خوش ہو، جب وہ غمگین ہو تو تم غمگین ہو۔\"",
        "",
        "میں نے اپنے دل میں جھانکا۔ کیا واقعی میں عدنان کے بغیر زندگی کا تصور کر سکتی تھی؟",
        "",
        "\"نہیں،\" میں نے آہستہ سے کہا۔ \"میں واقعی تمہارے بغیر زندگی کا تصور نہیں کر سکتی۔\"",
        "",
        "عدنان نے مسکرا کر میرا ہاتھ پکڑا۔ \"تو پھر یہ محبت ہے، ریحانہ۔\""
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-4',
      title: 'باب چہارم - عشق کی منزل',
      content: [
        "اس دن کے بعد، ہم دونوں نے اپنی محبت کا اعتراف کر لیا تھا۔",
        "",
        "عدنان نے میرے والدین سے ملنے کا فیصلہ کیا۔ میں بہت گھبرائی ہوئی تھی۔",
        "",
        "\"اگر میرے والدین نے انکار کر دیا تو؟\" میں نے پوچھا۔",
        "",
        "\"تو ہم انتظار کریں گے۔ سچی محبت ہمیشہ راستہ نکال لیتی ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "جب عدنان میرے گھر آیا، تو میرے والدین نے اسے پسند کیا۔ وہ پڑھا لکھا، نیک، اور اچھے خاندان سے تھا۔",
        "",
        "\"ریحانہ، کیا تم واقعی اس سے محبت کرتی ہو؟\" ابو نے پوچھا۔",
        "",
        "\"جی ابو، میں اس سے بہت محبت کرتی ہوں۔\"",
        "",
        "\"تو پھر ہماری رضامندی ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "ہم نے شادی کر لی، اور آج ہم بہت خوش ہیں۔ میں نے سیکھا کہ محبت واقعی زندگی کو خوبصورت بنا دیتی ہے۔",
        "",
        "عدنان کے ساتھ، میں نے جانا کہ عشق میں ہونا کیا ہوتا ہے۔"
      ]
    }
  ],
  excerpt: [
    "میرا نام ریحانہ ہے، اور یہ میری کہانی ہے کہ کیسے میں عشق میں پڑی۔"
  ],
  pages: 300,
  rating: 4.2,
  hasFullContent: true
};

novels.title: دل سے دل تک
novels.author: Amna Riaz
novels.description: دل سے دل تک امنہ ریاض کا ایک دلچسپ ناول ہے جو دو دلوں کے ملنے کی کہانی ہے۔
novels.rawContent:
export const dilSeDilTakNovel: Book = {
  id: 'dil-se-dil-tak',
  title: 'دل سے دل تک',
  author: 'Amna Riaz',
  authorId: 'amna-riaz',
  coverImage: 'https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Urdu_novel_cover.jpg/300px-Urdu_novel_cover.jpg',
  publishYear: 2020,
  language: 'ur',
  genre: ['Novel', 'Romance', 'Love Story', 'Contemporary', 'Emotional'],
  description: 'دل سے دل تک امنہ ریاض کا ایک دلچسپ ناول ہے جو دو دلوں کے ملنے کی کہانی ہے۔',
  chapters: [
    {
      id: 'chapter-1',
      title: 'باب اول - مصروف زندگی',
      content: [
        "میرا نام صفیہ ہے، اور یہ میری کہانی ہے کہ کیسے میرا دل کسی اور دل سے جڑا۔",
        "",
        "میں ایک ڈاکٹر تھی، اور میری زندگی بہت مصروف تھی۔ صبح سے شام تک ہسپتال میں مریضوں کا علاج کرتی، اور رات کو گھر آ کر تھک جاتی۔",
        "",
        "\"صفیہ، تم صرف کام کرتی رہتی ہو،\" میری ماں کہتی تھی۔ \"کبھی اپنے بارے میں بھی سوچو۔\"",
        "",
        "\"ماں، میرا کام ہی میری زندگی ہے۔ مریضوں کا علاج کرنا میرا جنون ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "\"لیکن بیٹی، شادی کے بارے میں بھی سوچو۔ تمہاری عمر ہو رہی ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "\"ماں، ابھی وقت ہے۔ پہلے میں اپنے کیریئر پر توجہ دینا چاہتی ہوں۔\"",
        "",
        "میں واقعی شادی کے بارے میں نہیں سوچتی تھی۔ میرے لیے میرا پیشہ سب کچھ تھا۔"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-2',
      title: 'باب دوم - نیا ساتھی',
      content: [
        "ایک دن، ہمارے ہسپتال میں ایک نیا ڈاکٹر آیا۔ اس کا نام ولید تھا۔",
        "",
        "وہ بہت ہنر مند اور محنتی تھا۔ مریضوں کے ساتھ اس کا برتاؤ بہت اچھا تھا۔",
        "",
        "\"ڈاکٹر صفیہ، آپ کا کام بہت متاثر کن ہے،\" اس نے ایک دن کہا۔",
        "",
        "\"شکریہ، ڈاکٹر ولید۔ آپ کا کام بھی بہت اچھا ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "آہستہ آہستہ ہم دونوں کے درمیان پیشہ ورانہ احترام پیدا ہوا۔ ہم مشکل کیسز پر مل کر کام کرتے۔",
        "",
        "\"صفیہ، آپ کے ساتھ کام کرنا بہت آسان ہے،\" ولید نے کہا۔ \"لگتا ہے جیسے ہم دونوں کی سوچ ملتی ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "\"مجھے بھی یہی لگتا ہے۔ جیسے ہم دونوں کا مقصد ایک ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "میں نے محسوس کیا کہ ولید کے ساتھ کام کرنا مجھے خوشی دیتا ہے۔"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-3',
      title: 'باب سوم - دل کا رشتہ',
      content: [
        "مہینے گزرتے گئے، اور ولید کے ساتھ میری دوستی گہری ہوتی گئی۔",
        "",
        "ایک دن، ہم ایک مشکل آپریشن کے بعد کیفے میں بیٹھے تھے۔",
        "",
        "\"صفیہ، کیا تم محسوس کرتی ہو کہ کچھ لوگوں کے دل آپس میں جڑے ہوتے ہیں؟\" ولید نے پوچھا۔",
        "",
        "میں نے اس کی طرف دیکھا۔ اس کی آنکھوں میں کچھ خاص تھا۔",
        "",
        "\"ہاں، اور میں محسوس کرتی ہوں کہ میرا دل تمہارے دل سے جڑا ہے،\" میں نے بے ساختہ کہا۔",
        "",
        "ولید نے مسکرا کر میرا ہاتھ پکڑا۔ \"میں بھی یہی محسوس کرتا ہوں۔\"",
        "",
        "\"لیکن ولید، ہم دونوں ڈاکٹر ہیں۔ کیا یہ ٹھیک ہوگا؟\"",
        "",
        "\"کیوں نہیں؟ جب دو لوگ ایک ہی مقصد رکھتے ہوں، تو وہ زندگی میں بھی ساتھ چل سکتے ہیں۔\"",
        "",
        "اس دن سے، ہم دونوں نے اپنی محبت کا اعتراف کر لیا۔"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-4',
      title: 'باب چہارم - دل سے دل تک',
      content: [
        "ولید نے میرے والدین سے ملنے کا فیصلہ کیا۔",
        "",
        "\"ماں، ولید ایک بہت اچھا ڈاکٹر ہے، اور میں اس سے محبت کرتی ہوں۔\"",
        "",
        "\"بیٹی، کیا تم واقعی خوش ہو؟\"",
        "",
        "\"جی ماں، بہت خوش ہوں۔ ولید میرے کام کو سمجھتا ہے، اور وہ بھی میری طرح مریضوں کی خدمت کرتا ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "جب ولید میرے گھر آیا، تو میرے والدین نے اسے پسند کیا۔",
        "",
        "\"ولید بیٹا، تم دونوں کا مقصد ایک ہے۔ یہ بہت اچھی بات ہے،\" ابو نے کہا۔",
        "",
        "ہم نے شادی کر لی، اور آج ہم ساتھ مل کر ایک کلینک چلاتے ہیں۔",
        "",
        "\"صفیہ، ہم نے ثابت کر دیا کہ جب دو دل ملتے ہیں، تو وہ زندگی میں بھی ساتھ چل سکتے ہیں،\" ولید کہتا ہے۔",
        "",
        "\"ہاں، ہمارا رشتہ واقعی دل سے دل تک ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "آج ہم سمجھتے ہیں کہ کچھ رشتے دل سے دل تک ہوتے ہیں، اور وہ زندگی بھر چلتے ہیں۔"
      ]
    }
  ],
  excerpt: [
    "میرا نام صفیہ ہے، اور یہ میری کہانی ہے کہ کیسے میرا دل کسی اور دل سے جڑا۔"
  ],
  pages: 280,
  rating: 4.3,
  hasFullContent: true
};

novels.title: متاع جان ہے تو
novels.author: Farhat Ishtiaq
novels.description: متاع جان ہے تو فرحت اشتیاق کا ایک کلاسک ناول ہے جو سچی محبت کی قیمت کے بارے میں ہے۔
novels.rawContent:
export const mataEJaanHaiTuNovel: Book = {
  id: 'mata-e-jaan-hai-tu',
  title: 'متاع جان ہے تو',
  author: 'Farhat Ishtiaq',
  authorId: 'farhat-ishtiaq',
  coverImage: 'https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Classic_urdu_novel.jpg/300px-Classic_urdu_novel.jpg',
  publishYear: 2016,
  language: 'ur',
  genre: ['Novel', 'Romance', 'Love Story', 'Classic', 'Drama'],
  description: 'متاع جان ہے تو فرحت اشتیاق کا ایک کلاسک ناول ہے جو سچی محبت کی قیمت کے بارے میں ہے۔',
  chapters: [
    {
      id: 'chapter-1',
      title: 'باب اول - امیری کا خلا',
      content: [
        "میرا نام جویریہ ہے، اور یہ میری کہانی ہے کہ کیسے میں نے اپنی جان کی متاع پائی۔",
        "",
        "میں ایک امیر گھرانے کی لڑکی تھی۔ ہمارے پاس بڑا گھر، گاڑیاں، نوکر چاکر، اور ہر قسم کی آسائشیں تھیں۔",
        "",
        "لیکن میرے دل میں ایک عجیب سا خلا تھا۔ جتنا بھی سامان خریدتی، جتنی بھی پارٹیوں میں جاتی، وہ خلا نہیں بھرتا تھا۔",
        "",
        "\"جویریہ، تم ہمیشہ اداس کیوں رہتی ہو؟\" میری ماں پوچھتی تھی۔ \"تمہارے پاس تو سب کچھ ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "\"ماں، میں نہیں جانتی۔ لگتا ہے جیسے کچھ کمی ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "\"کیا کمی ہو سکتی ہے؟ تم امیر گھرانے کی لڑکی ہو، پڑھی لکھی ہو، خوبصورت ہو۔\"",
        "",
        "لیکن میں جانتی تھی کہ یہ سب چیزیں میرے دل کا خلا نہیں بھر سکتیں۔"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-2',
      title: 'باب دوم - غریب کا امیر دل',
      content: [
        "ایک دن، میں اپنی سہیلی کے ساتھ یونیورسٹی گئی تھی۔ وہاں ایک چیریٹی ایونٹ ہو رہا تھا۔",
        "",
        "میں نے دیکھا کہ ایک نوجوان بہت محنت سے غریب بچوں کو کھانا کھلا رہا تھا۔ اس کے چہرے پر ایک نور تھا۔",
        "",
        "\"یہ کون ہے؟\" میں نے اپنی سہیلی سے پوچھا۔",
        "",
        "\"شہزاد۔ یہ یہاں پڑھتا ہے، لیکن بہت غریب ہے۔ اپنی فیس کے لیے پارٹ ٹائم کام کرتا ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "\"لیکن یہ اتنا خوش کیوں لگ رہا ہے؟\"",
        "",
        "\"کیونکہ یہ دوسروں کی خدمت کرتا ہے۔ کہتے ہیں کہ اس کا دل بہت امیر ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "میں نے شہزاد کو دیکھا۔ وہ ایک غریب لڑکا تھا، لیکن اس کے چہرے پر جو خوشی تھی، وہ میرے پاس نہیں تھی۔",
        "",
        "اس دن سے، میں اکثر اس کے بارے میں سوچنے لگی۔"
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-3',
      title: 'باب سوم - پہلی بات چیت',
      content: [
        "کچھ دنوں بعد، میں پھر یونیورسٹی گئی۔ شہزاد لائبریری میں پڑھ رہا تھا۔",
        "",
        "میں نے ہمت کر کے اس کے پاس جانے کا فیصلہ کیا۔",
        "",
        "\"ہیلو، میں جویریہ ہوں۔\"",
        "",
        "اس نے اوپر دیکھا اور مسکرایا۔ \"ہیلو، میں شہزاد ہوں۔\"",
        "",
        "\"میں نے آپ کو چیریٹی ایونٹ میں دیکھا تھا۔ آپ بہت اچھا کام کر رہے تھے۔\"",
        "",
        "\"شکریہ۔ یہ میرا شوق ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "\"شوق؟\"",
        "",
        "\"جی ہاں، دوسروں کی مدد کرنا۔ اس سے دل کو سکون ملتا ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "\"جویریہ، کیا تم سمجھتی ہو کہ زندگی کی اصل متاع کیا ہے؟\" اس نے اچانک پوچھا۔",
        "",
        "\"پیسہ؟\" میں نے جواب دیا۔",
        "",
        "\"نہیں، محبت۔ جب کوئی تمہاری جان بن جائے، تو وہی تمہاری اصل متاع ہے۔\""
      ]
    },
    {
      id: 'chapter-4',
      title: 'باب چہارم - جان کی متاع',
      content: [
        "شہزاد کے الفاظ نے میرے دل پر گہرا اثر کیا۔ میں اس سے ملتی رہی، اور آہستہ آہستہ اس سے محبت ہونے لگی۔",
        "",
        "\"جویریہ، تم ایک امیر گھرانے کی لڑکی ہو، اور میں ایک غریب لڑکا ہوں،\" شہزاد نے ایک دن کہا۔",
        "",
        "\"تو کیا ہوا؟ محبت میں امیری غریبی نہیں دیکھی جاتی۔\"",
        "",
        "\"لیکن تمہارے والدین کبھی نہیں مانیں گے۔\"",
        "",
        "\"میں انہیں سمجھاؤں گی۔\"",
        "",
        "جب میں نے گھر جا کر اپنے والدین کو شہزاد کے بارے میں بتایا، تو وہ بہت ناراض ہوئے۔",
        "",
        "\"جویریہ، تم پاگل ہو گئی ہو؟ ایک غریب لڑکے سے محبت؟\"",
        "",
        "\"ابو، شہزاد غریب ضرور ہے، لیکن اس کا دل بہت امیر ہے۔\"",
        "",
        "\"دل سے پیٹ نہیں بھرتا۔\"",
        "",
        "لیکن میں نے ہار نہیں مانی۔ میں نے سیکھا کہ شہزاد میری جان کی متاع ہے، اور میں اس کے بغیر کچھ بھی نہیں۔",
        "",
        "آخر میں، میرے والدین نے شہزاد کی نیکی اور محنت دیکھ کر اسے قبول کر لیا۔",
        "",
        "آج ہم خوش ہیں، کیونکہ ہم نے سیکھا کہ اصل متاع محبت ہے، پیسہ نہیں۔"
      ]
    }
  ],
  excerpt: [
    "میرا نام جویریہ ہے، اور یہ میری کہانی ہے کہ کیسے میں نے اپنی جان کی متاع پائی۔"
  ],
  pages: 350,
  rating: 4.4,
  hasFullContent: true
};
